questions.text: What is Docker?

answers.description: Version control systems like Git manage changes to source code.
Docker is a platform that enables developers to build, ship, and run applications in containers, which are lightweight, standalone, and executable software packages.
Text editors like VS Code are used for writing and editing code.
Programming languages like Java or Python are used to write software applications.

questions.text: What is a Dockerfile used for?

answers.description: Data storage is typically managed through volumes or databases.
A Dockerfile is a script that contains instructions for building a Docker image, which defines the environment for running a container.
Running containers is done using Docker commands.
Monitoring containers is generally done through logging and observability tools.

questions.text: What is the purpose of Docker Compose?

answers.description: Compiling Java code is not the purpose of Docker Compose.

answers.text: To define and run multi-container applications
answers.description: Docker Compose is a tool for defining and running multi-container Docker applications. It uses a YAML file to specify the services, networks, and volumes needed for an application.

answers.text: To deploy containers to the cloud
answers.description: Deployment to the cloud is generally done through other tools or services.
Editing source code is done in text editors or IDEs.

questions.text: What does a Docker image contain?

answers.description: An image contains more than just source code.
An image contains more than just dependencies.
A Docker image contains both the application's source code and its dependencies, making it a standalone, executable package.
An image is designed to be a complete package for running an application.

questions.text: What is a Docker container?

answers.text: A running instance of a Docker image
answers.description: A Docker container is a running instance of a Docker image. It encapsulates the application and its environment.
A storage unit for data is generally referred to as a volume in Docker terminology.
Version control systems like Git are different from Docker.
Docker itself is not a cloud service, although it can interact with them.

questions.text: What is a Docker volume?

answers.description: Network protocols are not related to Docker volumes.

answers.text: A storage mechanism for persistent data
answers.description: Docker volumes are used for storing persistent data generated by and used by Docker containers.
Container orchestration tools like Kubernetes are different from Docker volumes.
While security is important, it's not what Docker volumes are primarily used for.

questions.text: What is Docker Hub?

answers.description: Container orchestration tools like Kubernetes are different from Docker Hub.
Docker Hub is a cloud-based registry service where you can upload and download Docker images.
Version control systems like Git are not the same as Docker Hub.
Monitoring services are not the primary function of Docker Hub.

questions.text: What is the primary language for writing Dockerfiles?

answers.description: YAML is used for Docker Compose files, not Dockerfiles.
JSON is not used for writing Dockerfiles.
While shell commands can be run in a Dockerfile, the primary language is Dockerfile DSL.
Dockerfiles are written in Dockerfile DSL (Domain Specific Language), which is a set of specific commands understood by Docker for building images.

questions.text: What is the command to build a Docker image?

answers.description: docker run is used to run a container.
docker pull is used to download an image.
docker push is used to upload an image to a registry.
The docker build command is used to build a Docker image from a Dockerfile.

questions.text: What is the command to run a Docker container?

answers.description: docker exec is used to run a command in a running container.
docker build is used to build an image.
The docker run command is used to create and start a Docker container from an image.
docker compose is used for defining and running multi-container applications.

questions.text: What is the difference between a Docker image and a Docker container?

answers.description: They are fundamentally different.

answers.text: An image is a running instance, and a container is a static file
answers.description: This is the opposite of the correct answer.

answers.text: An image is a static file, and a container is a running instance
answers.description: A Docker image is a static file that contains the application and its dependencies, while a Docker container is a running instance of that image.

answers.text: A container is a newer version of an image
answers.description: A container is not necessarily a newer version of an image.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the `EXPOSE` command in a Dockerfile?

answers.description: Environment variables are managed using the **`ENV`** command.
The **`EXPOSE`** command in a Dockerfile informs Docker that the container will listen on the specified network ports at runtime.
Volumes are managed using the **`VOLUME`** command.
Services are generally defined in Docker Compose files.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the `CMD` command in a Dockerfile?

answers.text: To execute shell commands during build
answers.description: Shell commands during build are executed using the **`RUN`** command.

answers.text: To specify the default command to run when the container starts
answers.description: The **`CMD`** command in a Dockerfile specifies the default command that will be executed when the container is run.

answers.text: To copy files into the image
answers.description: Files are copied using the **`COPY`** command.
Environment variables are set using the **`ENV`** command.

questions.text: What is Docker Swarm?

answers.description: A container registry is where Docker images are stored.
Docker Swarm is a native clustering and orchestration solution for Docker. It allows you to manage multiple containers deployed across multiple host machines.
Version control systems like Git are not related to Docker Swarm.
Monitoring tools are separate from Docker Swarm, although Swarm does have some basic monitoring capabilities.

questions.text: What is the `docker-compose up` command used for?

answers.text: To build images defined in a **`docker-compose.yml`** file
answers.description: While it can build images if they don't exist, its primary function is to start services.

answers.text: To start services defined in a **`docker-compose.yml`** file
answers.description: The **`docker-compose up`** command is used to start up all the services defined in a **`docker-compose.yml`** file.

answers.text: To upload images to Docker Hub
answers.description: Uploading images to Docker Hub is done using **`docker push`**.

answers.text: To download images from Docker Hub
answers.description: Downloading images is done using **`docker pull`**.

questions.text: What is the `--link` flag used for in Docker?

answers.description: The **`--link`** flag is used to link two containers, allowing them to communicate with each other. However, it's considered a legacy feature and is generally replaced by Docker networks.

answers.text: To link a container to a volume
answers.description: Volumes are not linked using the **`--link`** flag.

answers.text: To link a container to a network
answers.description: Networks are generally managed differently.

answers.text: To link a container to a Dockerfile
answers.description: A Dockerfile is not linked to a container using the **`--link`** flag.

questions.text: What is the purpose of a `.dockerignore` file?

answers.text: To specify files and directories to ignore during a **`docker build`**
answers.description: A **`.dockerignore`** file is used to specify files and directories that should be ignored during the **`docker build`** process, similar to how **`.gitignore`** works for Git.
Environment variables are generally set in the Dockerfile or Docker Compose file.
Network settings are not managed through **`.dockerignore`**.
Container orchestration settings are generally managed in Docker Compose or other orchestration tools.

questions.text: What is the purpose of Docker namespaces?

answers.description: Docker uses namespaces to provide a layer of isolation between containers. Namespaces restrict what a container can see and do, thereby enhancing security and isolation.
Build settings are generally specified in the Dockerfile.
Volumes are managed through other mechanisms.
Images are not managed through namespaces.

questions.text: What is the `docker exec` command used for?

answers.text: To execute a command in a running container
answers.description: The **`docker exec`** command is used to execute a command in a running container, often for debugging or administrative tasks.

answers.text: To execute a command in a stopped container
answers.description: Commands cannot be executed in a stopped container.
Stopping a container is done using **`docker stop`**.
Building a Docker image is done using **`docker build`**.

questions.text: What is a Docker service in the context of Docker Swarm?

answers.text: A group of containers with the same image and configuration
answers.description: In the context of Docker Swarm, a service is a group of containers that are created from the same image and share the same configuration. Services allow you to scale and manage containers more easily.
A single container is not considered a service in Docker Swarm.
A Docker registry is not a service in the context of Docker Swarm.
Network protocols are not services in the context of Docker Swarm.
